I think you'd be best just focusing in one discipline and getting really good at it while passively learning the other. When the time comes and you're ready to pick up the latter skill it will all start to make sense quick. Remember you'll likely have a team so if you get really good at AI/ML and just follow cyber news, your team will be able to advise you where you're not an expert. Frameworks would become your best friend. And if you choose to get really good with cyber, introducing AI/ML is essentially the same kind of transition as Cybersecurity Analyst -> Cybersecurity Engineer with some extra layers. The earlier you specialize the better IMO, I'd say research how AI is used in SIEM, SOAR, NGFW, or other tools and become a true subject matter expert on one or two of them.

Depends on what you want your role to be - in general, likely best to lean towards applied cybersecurity - AI-accelerated cybersecurity technology on GPUs is being platformed by folks like NVIDIA themselves (look at their Morpheus service) - and the rise of LLMs supplants most needs to understand the neural networks that underly deep learning as foundational models do not know or care if they are being applied to NLP, vision, or, in this case, anomaly detection. The main practical difference is in the embeddings of the models, I suppose, but, more importantly, the data that they are being trained on. That all is more the job of our data scientists. Just a thought. Do you want to be 'in' cybersecurity or do you want to be on a data science team that trains LLMs on how to infer anomaly detection?

We want to know how you envision artificial intelligence (AI) shaping the field of medicine in the upcoming years. üß†üí° Share your thoughts and concerns regarding AI's role in medicine, and let's explore the exciting possibilities together! üó£üí¨

Health providers in my experience already take in a five-minute soundbite of summary information about an ongoing medical condition, and then generically prescribe a "best practice" protocol or treatment strategy that sounds like it came from a pharma journal or maybe a statistical averaging from some WHO database of past malpractice lawsuits.  

It's such an automated and depersonalized process already, that just directly talking to a machine in the first place will surely not be so much different.  More expensive maybe, until the AI's patent expires and a generic version comes available; but subjectively the same experience.

A significant change however, is that up to now when a human doctor's prescription is particularly out to lunch or illogical, it has been possible to read through their notes and pick up clues as to where the patient omitted an important detail or where the doctor mis- heard what the patient said.  If an AI is a black box, such confusion will be more difficult to debug.

Yes, AI can do medicine in a variety of ways. Here are some examples:

Diagnosis: AI can be used to analyze medical images and data to help doctors diagnose diseases more accurately. For example, AI-powered systems have been shown to be just as accurate as human radiologists at detecting breast cancer.
Prognosis: AI can be used to predict the course of a disease and the likelihood of a patient's recovery. This information can help doctors make better treatment decisions and provide patients with more accurate information about their prognosis.
Treatment: AI can be used to develop new treatments for diseases. For example, AI-powered systems are being used to design new drugs and to optimize the dosage of existing drugs.
Personalized medicine: AI can be used to create personalized treatment plans for patients. This is done by taking into account a patient's individual genetic makeup, medical history, and other factors.
Healthcare administration: AI can be used to automate tasks in healthcare administration, such as scheduling appointments, processing claims, and managing patient records. This can free up time for healthcare professionals to focus on patient care.
AI is still a relatively new field, and there are many challenges that need to be addressed before it can be fully integrated into medicine. However, the potential benefits of AI for medicine are significant, and it is likely to play an increasingly important role in the future of healthcare.

Here are some of the challenges that need to be addressed before AI can be fully integrated into medicine:

Data availability: AI-powered systems require large amounts of data to train and operate. This data can be difficult and expensive to obtain, especially for rare diseases.
Bias: AI systems can be biased if they are trained on data that is not representative of the population. This can lead to inaccurate diagnoses and treatment recommendations.
Interpretability: It can be difficult to understand how AI systems make decisions. This can make it difficult to trust these systems and to use them in clinical settings.
Despite these challenges, AI has the potential to revolutionize medicine. It can help doctors diagnose diseases more accurately, predict the course of a disease, and develop personalized treatment plans. AI can also automate tasks in healthcare administration, freeing up time for healthcare professionals to focus on patient care. The future of medicine is likely to be increasingly influenced by AI, and it is an exciting time to be involved in this field.

I know a PH.D who did research on AI and treatment actually from 2010. He was mainly in the programming and engineering aspect, but their research also heavily involved patient reactions to robots or AI. They had a massive sample size, and one of the biggest hurdles of nonhuman treatment was patient aversion. Overwhelming amount of people wanted human interaction when it came to treatment.

I was also part of observing effects of AI and internal medicine at a very large research hospital that I cannot disclose.

One of the benefits of AI was prelim. diagnosis which was pretty good and faster than people. One thing the AI had trouble with was complexities and needs of different humans. The AI could not ‚Äúlogically‚Äù assess why some people reacted differently to a treatment. Basically it had trouble reasoning why people are all different despite facts and data about human physiology.

What was really disturbing here was it tended to focus on patient data that fit the medical facts, and rules out people who did not respond to medication as they ‚Äúsupposed to‚Äù as experimental error.‚Äù

Alright, let's, once again, tune down the horror of the situation because apparently, when it comes to this thing we call "thinking", people are really not bright:

- This kind of system can only work if you wear a BCI (brain-computer interface). And that's something you'd wear WILLINGLY, no one can force you to do it. No one can just read your minds by looking at you, they'd need access to the system that your BCI is logged onto.
- This research is important for A LOT of medical cases. This will help us communicate with people in vegetative state. This will let the doctors understand what you perceive precisely. People with hallucinations, or with sensory "bugs", this sort of mechanism will help us understand more about their conditions.
- This also matters for us to get even more advanced tchnology than current one. Imagine not having to type on a keyboard _at all_ to do anything on the computer. We could just literally communicate with the machine, through thoughts. Keyboards made writing faster ; a proper BCI would make it _instantaneous._

Are there risks? Yes, of course. Like absolutely everything. You create a hammer, someone will use it to smash heads. You create a car, someone will use it to roll over people. We do have to be aware of the risks and prevent them, but stop being so stupidly horrified by technological advancements. They all matter.

Two things. I am truly intrigued by this discovery, as it highlights a type of progression necessary to the growth and further industrialization of our civilization. However!! Two: this is alarming. Already, corporations can both observe and pave the way for our consumeristic habits by simply reviewing our demographics, buying habits, interests, etc, through the virtual data they gather. And these are simple methods that are not only quite effective but nearly invisible. So imagine what big corp, or anyone in this case, could do by observing and understanding what we think. Already, NBC has triggered a baiting with the header ‚ÄúStudy: AI brain activity decoder can reveal stories in people‚Äôs minds‚Äù.. although eye catching, already we‚Äôve been mislead by a company to believe that AI can now display stories in our minds, when that‚Äôs just not the whole truth. So if it‚Äôs already possible for a simple attention grabber like that, it is troublesome to imagine what can come next in the future from a different company with a different objective with different means to their end. But overall, I‚Äôm excited üòã

Some people might scream ‚Äú1984 THOUGHT POLICE!!‚Äù and I understand their concerns. Nothing is more private than our thoughts and we all deserve mental privacy. However, this technology also has the potential for a lot of good. As the woman said in the video, it could help people with neurodegenerative conditions such as Parkinson‚Äôs and ALS. It could also allow us to communicate with our canine friends and other animals. Maybe even dolphins! I think that would be morally just and beneficial for both humans and animals. Another possible benefit is that it could improve the justice system. Imagine if only guilty people were convicted and no more wrongful death sentences were issued. Lie detectors and interrogations would be obsolete and maybe even courts would be unnecessary if this tech could reveal the truth with certainty. Of course, there are also risks and challenges. If this tech becomes widely available, it could be abused by malicious actors or hackers. The idea of someone pointing their phone at me and reading my mind without my consent is terrifying. Especially if they find out some of my kinky fantasies! But like it or not, mind reading and other amazing sci-fi AI tech are finally becoming reality. I wish there was a cure for aging too, so I could live long enough to see all of it and have a purpose in life.

Im surprised this took so long to get news coverage. This study is called "Semantic reconstruction of continuous language from non-invasive brain recordings" published in BioRxiv, a non peer reviewed archive of scholarly articles. What they didn't tell you in the video is that each subjects testing had to be individualized, with 100% cooperation of the subject. The AI decoder had to first be trained by recording the subjects brain while they listened to around 16 hours of audio narrative data. This technology is nowhere neer being able to read people brains on a whim, and they did tests in study to prove it.

What AI boils down to is pattern recognition. Anywhere there is an underlying pattern, AI can eventually learn to read those patterns with enough data. Its all about the data though. AI will be changing the world as we know it, in every aspect of society.

Horrible and dishonest reporting to get clicks.

Said this elsewhere, but I'm going to put it here in hopes of people reading it:

Don't be afraid, man, it's BS. It says directly in the paper that it takes human cooperation to both train and apply things. Also, it's an fMRI, so it is objectively not reading "brain waves" as they say in this video - it's blood flow, like with every other fMRI study (these are extremely vague and slow compared to how fast the brain actually works, and doesn't take known complexity into account - it is NOT getting words or ideas from your brain the way they claim here). What it actually is, is simply AI filling grammatical gaps, and the content comes from basic, trained pattern recognition. If you've ever seen that episode of House where the person with locked in syndrome communicates "yes" or "no" by thinking it enough times, then you understand what this is. That's all it is, and this isn't new technology. It's simply adding AI to data given by a method we already have in use.

Well, i think you would find it interesting that this news story vastly misrepresented the findings by leaving out vital details.

You see, the 3 participants in the language decoding test first had to listen to around 16 hours of an audiobook narrative (with 100% focus and cooperation) whilst the fMRI collected data that the AI decoder then used to correlate specific brain activity with the audio book data. 

Each participant had to be individuallized in the study because everyones brain is slightly different - meaning the data collected from one participant can not be used to accurately decode other participants. They did tests to confirm this. Furthermore, they did other tests that found that the AI could not decode language during activities unrelated to the data collected during the audiobook. 

There are other limitations they ran into that relate to the fMRI technology itself. To explain, it takes around 10 seconds for the blood oxygen levels to rise in a certain brain area in response to nueral activation. In that 10 seconds, countless other thoughts occur before the fMRI could detect them. This leaves quite a big window for error. To combat this, the researchers had the participants listen to the same segments of audio data multiple times. Keep in mind that the participants have to actively focus on and visualize the audio data for the ai decoder to be accurate.

Although it is scary to think what this might turn into in coming decades, it is nowhere the capabilities of reading peoples brains on the whim, as they made it seem in the news story. 

Some youtubers i recommend you look into for no bs, cutting edge science news are "Anton Petrov" and "Sabine Hossenfelder" 

I also recommend learning to read from Primary/scholarly sources as well. It is hard to trust science from most news media outlets because they typically feer monger and blatantly misrepresent scientific data, as with this news video.

Source: Tang, Jerry; et al., "Semantic reconstruction of continuous language from non-invasive brain recordings". BioRxiv, 2022

Evolution vs food.

Food disproves evolution.
Every organism no matter how small either manufacturers or collects food or it would die very quickly.

Every organism identifies, ingests, digests, filters, stores, and excretes food.

It has to identify the difference between food or rock.

It must ingests food through a specialized opening designed to intake only food and nothing else.

The worst thing: since we actually dont have a theory of everything. You literally assume existence of an additional group and you can "hide" a literal copy of our universe in a series of very quick cyclic transitions of the quantum property corresponding to charge. Basically its not like there is an electron being an electron and a positron which has been missing for almost 14 billion years for no reason. Its about electron and positron having initially recieved not a spacial offset relative to one another but a miniscule offset IN TIME and a reaction which takes one electron and turns it into its antiparticle ‚Äì positron with one necessary condition: doing it really really quick, without changing its momentum and finally doing it with extreme probability. Given those conditions a bunch of particles which were created with one more condition, namely having been created simultaniously would have met each other all being matter at one point in time simultaniously and would have met each other now all being antimatter at another point in time simultaniously thus creating the illusion that for some reason we only have to deal with matter while missing out on antimatter almost completely. The only reason that we usually assume a different set of symmetries to be the reason our universe exists, is because we tend to chose the most primitive set of symmetries when it comes about speculating about what must have existed in the first place. And absurdly enough we dont deem the obvious lack of antimatter all around us as in we do not tend to witness annihilation of all existing matter in the universe all around us everywhere to be scientific enough and a reason to actually assume something more complex than the most basic case we can mathematically describe. As scary as this sounds, they need a freaking MRI machine to do it at a distance. This isn't something where "they will just make it more widely scannable". As in order to do that, we'd basically need a room temperature superconducting electromagnet capable of generating soul shattering magnetic fields. Which would send anything made of steel flying towards it, shredding anybody in its path. Or we'd need an entirely new, completely undiscovered method of remotely and scanning someone's brain without interacting with anything else around its vicinity, or releasing high doses of radiation. So as the news failed to mention, we aren't anywhere near "mindreading scanners on every cell phone and traffic light" yet. This technology (as it is in our era) will do far more good for disabled people than it does bad for everyone else. If you are still paranoid, just basically don't let the government glue big computer monitored brain scanners to your head, and you know they aren't listening to your thoughts.

The fact that Americans aren't burning the companies making this stuff down shows you how compliant our populace has become. You'll all be freely letting companies and the government read your thoughts 24/7 soon.

This is a double edge sword, if it can be used for good, it can also be used for nefarious purposes. For example: A crime happens,  the police use Facial Recognition (which is only 40% accurate) to "identify" a suspect (let's say the wrong person/innocent person) and they "find" this  person who is innocent and connect that person to this machine, and because the person is so upset and confused, the machine misinterprets what the human mind is actually thinking/feeling in that moment and reads something totally different. Who are the Cops going to believe, the Suspect or the AI? I think we all know the answer to that.

In that scenario the innocent person will be scared, but there's a difference. They won't know exactly what the crime is or why they are getting pulled over. But in the case when the innocent person that's pulled over and does know what kind of crime it is then it isn't as obvious. But there is still a difference in thought from a real criminal where the innocent person is nervous because he knows that he's innocent but is afraid that it might pick up on him being a criminal. Where as the real criminal is nervous that he will be caught because he is is guilty.

That being said I still rather not having this technology available but there is nothing we could do about it unless all the governments in the world cracks down on the advancement in AI. But I'm afraid that we are already too late with that because AI is already in the stage of programming its own self. I believe We as a species are already doomed. How much does my plant understand when I talk to it?  A deliberate schedule of watering.  Light.  No light. Changing direction of light. Sequences. Various periods. Different intensities of light.  Different colors of light.  Different temperatures at different times of day.  Ok.  This is the stimuli I engineer.  Then I wait for my friend to respond.  Beyond reading its simple tropisms in a literal way, i.e., going greener, or growing browner, growing in this or that direction faster or slower to indicate what it NEEDS from us to survive, how do we read its behavior to discover what a plant really WANTS in this life? How do we distinguish of these tropisms what the plant actually WANTS from the behaviors we see and incentivize it to exhibit?  Sometimes you do things you don't want to achieve a much larger goal. What if I am not being facetious?

Well, actually, there is some feer mongering here as it seems they blatantly left out vital details of the study.ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 

You see, the 3 participants in the language decoding test first had to listen to around 16 hours of an audiobook narrative (with 100% focus and cooperation) whilst the fMRI collected data that the AI decoder then used to correlate specific brain activity with the audio book data. 

Each participant had to be individuallized in the study because everyones brain is slightly different - meaning the data collected from one participant can not be used to accurately decode other participants. They did tests to confirm this. Furthermore, they did other tests that found that the AI could not decode language during activities unrelated to the data collected during the audiobook. 

There are other limitations they ran into that relate to the fMRI technology itself. To explain, it takes around 10 seconds for the blood oxygen levels to rise in a certain brain area in response to nueral activation. In that 10 seconds, countless other thoughts occur before the fMRI could detect them. This leaves quite a big window for error. To combat this, the researchers had the participants listen to the same segments of audio data multiple times. Keep in mind that the participants have to actively be focusing on and visualizing the audio data for the ai decoder to be accurate.

Although it is scary to think what this might turn into in coming decades, it is nowhere the capabilities of reading peoples brains on the whim, as they made it seem in the news story. 

Source: Tang, Jerry; et al., "Semantic reconstruction of continuous language from non-invasive brain recordings". BioRxiv, 2022

@tt9ck¬† I'm very aware of how rapidly technology is evolving, but it's not magic. You need sensors attached to a person's head to read brain waves, it's fundamentally impossible to read those brain waves from a distance through the air. No matter how advanced technology becomes we won't be able to do that, just like we'll never get telekinesis powers. Maybe one day we'll all have chips in our brain, but you'll be aware of it at the very least.

@lizzys BEAUTY show etc.¬† The algorithms these companies use are very intricate. Most of their money goes into perfecting advertising because that's where they get their money from, so your tendencies are compared to other profiles and they draw conclusions from there. That is to say, because you searched about this and that, and these other people on the internet who searched the same thing as you also searched for orchids, then the algorithm draws the conclusion that you might also want orchids even if you never searched for orchids. What you're experiencing is simply the result of all of your data getting compared with other people's data to make a prediction on what you might be interested in.

@@lizzysbeautyshowetc.6895 Your phones and computers can listen in on your conversations to get keywords to remember. One time I was talking about bees to my brother and pretty much right after that I look on Pinterest and yet there it was bees. Pretty dumb example, but you get the point. In the case of music its simple because we've only defined several key notes.  But a brain obviously defines much much more, but the process is the same.  Whats needed is something that can handle that amount of information and process it into  notes per say.  So when you think of a truck and the brains electric response reflects to that thought, the computer and ai needs to decipher among the many electrical patterns what that note will likely be. This has happened a lot specifically on Amazon and on instagram. I tested this back in high school. My history teacher was also interested in it because he too had experienced it. I decided to do this because I had been talking about toothpaste in class and that night I saw an ad for you guessed it. And I had not done or searched anything on my phone involving toothpaste. I also hadn‚Äôt recently seen any advertisements about toothpaste. I noticed this happened a few times before so I had enough. You don‚Äôt really see many ads for toothpaste anyways. I had them (as many people that actually wanted to see if it was true) pick 3 random products or brands to just talk about through the week. It also had to be something they never interact with on their device through searching, following, or anything. We put as much effort as we could into making sure people were going to talk about things that they would not normally get ads for. Well, it was scary. Over 80% of those students (most of whom were my friends) had a ‚Äútargeted ad‚Äù on a product that they had spoken about frequently near their phone. I believe in small coincidence, but at some point you have to wonder ‚Äú why do I keep seeing ads for products or items that I talk about when I‚Äôm around my phone? This is a huge issue and I 100% believe it to be true after my experiences

Two entirely different things. You're assuming that animals perceive and communicate things in the same way we do, which is false. People constantly personify animals as if they have the same emotions we do. Look the dog is happy! It is sad! It is melancholy. It is contemplative. They don't experience the world in the same way nor have the same responses to it that we do. Could we make up paradigms and models to make it seem like they're speaking English? Sure. Does that mean they experience and feel as we do? Absolutely not. Dogs primary way of experiencing the world is through scent that is thousands of times more sensitive than ours. We couldn't even imagine what their experience is. The mantis shrimp has TEN more color receptors than we do. It can see colors that we can't. And there's no way to give an example of that because we have to change everything to colors we can see to see them. Different animals experience life differently than we do. And they have different "emotions" that go with it

@@gumdum5258 For an understanding of relationships between objects A and B, put one isolated image of A in front of creature, then measure brain activity. Put another isolated image of B in front of creature, then measure brain activity. Then put some interaction between A and B in front of creature. Then measure brain activity. There is your brain map right there.  When you recognize the same topology of brain activity, you know what they are thinking. While your excitement about the potential benefits of this technology is understandable, especially for non-verbal individuals, it's also crucial to consider the potential dangers that a literal mind-reading AI could bring.

There are significant privacy concerns. If this technology falls into the wrong hands, it could be used to extract information directly from someone's brain without their knowledge or consent, effectively eliminating the last vestiges of personal privacy. Our thoughts are the final frontier of our private selves, and having technology that can intrude upon that space is potentially a troubling development.

This is a very interesting development for both patients and doctors. I think this brings up an interesting debate about privacy of the patient. Most of us would agree that every human is entitled to some form of privacy while in the medical setting, but this technology might encroach on that right but for the betterment of the patient. I think I would personally accept that tradeoff, if this AI can truly pick up on manifestations of medical conditions before physicians and nurses could notice them, I would want this in a hospital I was at. I think this does lean into the debate of sacrificing some of our person liberties for health. This is sacrificing your own person liberty of privacy to ensure your health is okay and people do something similar every day with feeding data into let‚Äôs say an apple watch to be analyzed, or a continues glucose monitoring device for people with diabetes. Where this debate gets a little cloudier is are people willing to sacrifice their own right to privacy for the good of their community.  We saw this in COVID-19 when people were encouraged to get the vaccine even though if there were to contract COVID there symptoms might be mild but getting the vaccine protected those who were more vulnerable like the elderly and immunocompromised . 1 I think this second debate between sacrificing person liberties for the health of a community is a hard idea to get behind especially in the United States where our culture values person freedom so much. Setting that debate aside though I think this new technology has the chance to benefit patients and allow doctors to better care for patients. This might also improve justice in the healthcare system by mitigating physician bias both conscious and unconscious because this AI won‚Äôt have those biases.

I also have concerns about how this might affect specifically the American medical system. If this does take some burden off physicians and nurses would the hospital systems, then be inclined to hire less health care providers. I fear with the way our medical system is set up this might be something that happens, and I believe even with this technology this would be to the detriment of the patient if this were to infact happen. I think this is a tool for physicians and nurses to use and not a replacement for the daily interactions that patients have with the staff at a hospital.
Another issue is its use for risk assessments and insurance. I have a few guesses how actuaries and insurance personnel will use this data to deny payment or influence reimbursement.

This technology sounds like it would help healthcare workers significantly. This program also is able to assist with being able to provide faster assistance and better-quality assistance to patients. There are a few points I would like to touch on regarding this technology.  First, I would like to touch on informed consent. To provide background, informed consent encompasses being able to disclose the information fully, make sure the patient understands what is happening with their care, and that they voluntarily provide their consent unless they are okay with someone else making the decision. With all this data being collected, there becomes the concern with making sure that patients are truly okay with having this data being collected, they know how their information is being used, and they understand how the monitoring works. With technology, especially in medicine, rapidly evolving these questions of how to utilize this technology ethically becomes more and more of a concern and needs to be addressed. Many patients want to know everything involved in their care and some patients may not be okay with this technology being utilized or may mistrust how their information is being used. Therefore, making sure that patients truly understand what this program is doing and how it is going to benefit their care is so crucial. Another aspect that patients may be concerned about is how their information is being kept private. If this technology monitors a patient‚Äôs movements while they are staying in the hospital, then some patients and their families may be concerned with maintaining their own privacy. As more technological programs like this one begin to be more incorporated into medicine, all of these concerns need to be addressed so that patients feel like their privacy and their control over their healthcare isn‚Äôt being violated.

I completely agree with the perspectives in this video and love what this hospital is doing, being a leader in innovation. The potential of technology integration in healthcare is incredible. While there are challenges to overcome, the benefits of these integrations can have a significant impact on reducing health disparities and improving patient care. One of the most significant advantages of implementing these systems is the ability to provide healthcare workers with real-time patient data. This allows for quicker and more informed decision-making, ultimately leading to improved patient outcomes. Additionally, by automating certain tasks, healthcare providers can optimize their time and resources, enabling them to be more proactive in-patient interventions. However, the effectiveness of artificial intelligence is heavily reliant on the quality and quantity of data it receives. It is essential to ensure that the data being used is representative of diverse patient populations to avoid contributing to health disparities. There is also a need to balance the use of technology with the importance of human interaction and the personal touch that healthcare providers bring to patient care. Privacy concerns are also a significant consideration in technology integration in healthcare. Patients must have clear information about what data is being collected, how it is being used, and who has access to it. Patients must have the ability to provide informed consent and have control over their personal health information even if it is basic information like movement patterns, body temperature, and facial expressions. It is crucial to recognize that technology integration is not a one-size-fits-all solution. Each healthcare system and patient population has unique needs and challenges that must be taken into consideration when implementing these systems. While there are barriers to overcome with artificial intelligence in healthcare, the potential benefits of technology integration in healthcare are vast. By carefully addressing concerns around data quality, privacy, and individual patient needs, we can harness the power of technology to improve patient outcomes and reduce health disparities. I don‚Äôt think we should be too eager to rapidly adopt, because that is where we can run into issues. We must be careful and watch our step as we tread into utilizing this technology in all aspects of modern life.

I would be interested in seeing the cost analysis of this system. Would this be largely covered by insurance companies, or would it better suit an "out-of-pocket‚Äù health model? If it is meant to be implemented as a new standard of care at the University of Florida Health Center, the concept of bedside rationing must be considered. This idea is best described by Bernard Lo in his book Resolving Ethical Dilemmas: ‚ÄúPhysicians are ethically obligated to act in patients‚Äô best interests. Acting in the best interests of one patient, however, might sometimes preclude physicians from acting on behalf of another patient who is much more likely to benefit from care or from stewarding scarce resources.‚Äù This idea challenges the moral obligation to uphold beneficence, which is defined as having your best interests for the patient (Lo, 2019).  At this point, the use of this AI technology is costly and rare. Although this could be used as an effective tool for healthcare teams, the question then becomes if it should be used. In theory, even if this AI tool helps patients with their care at the hospital, it can potentially dramatically damage their wallets. As a future physician, it feels irresponsible to not take a patient‚Äôs financial status into account when developing a care plan. I believe although helpful, at this point in time it is not deemed essential for qualitative care. In America‚Äôs current healthcare system, the money is better spent elsewhere. For instance, due to the nationwide shortage of healthcare professionals, using funds towards providing more jobs and incentives for medical workers to continue to pursue the healthcare field seems to better fit the current model of care. However, if this becomes more cost efficient, I am in favor of technology as a guidance tool, but not a replacement for physicians and nurses.

I think that is a legitimate fear to have. It is a scary thought when a new technology is introduced and its function is to do parts of someone's job arguably better. It is unfortunate, but not uncommon, that groups of people may act to change the business model or care-plan as a reaction to the new technology and its performance. However, some of the limits I have read about regarding artificial intelligence technology are that there functions are limited to their datasets and that the recommendations they make do not always give a reason as to why it is being given.  
I think Dr. Rashidi summarizes those limitations based on the description of machine learning, or the ability for technology to do a function based on the data it receives. With the function of this specific technology seeming to be more focused on improving patient interactions by assessing physical responses that are abnormal to a person, the recommendations the machine makes may be more so focused on occupational recommendations and improving communication to providers to see someone sooner rather than later. Preventatively, consulting people who are suspicious of an emergent event as soon as possible has been proven to lower patient costs and hospital stays, but those consultations still require people with hands-on skills and adaptive thinking to take all the information that is in front of them in order to provide quality care. I would say that these technologies are simply acting as way to simplify that communication and will always need quality staff to deliver care, but now those staff may be required to learn how to coordinate care with these machines as point-of-care tools.

A love letter in a style of a pirate from the 14th century that has an Irish accent, but is from the Bahamas:
Ahoy, me heart's delight,

In the midst of these turquoise waters and beneath the golden sun of the Bahamas, me heart has found its true compass ‚Äì and that compass points straight to ye. By the saints of the sea, I be captivated by the glint in yer eyes, like stars twinklin' on a clear night, guidin' me ship through treacherous waters.

Surely, me days were but shadows before ye crossed me path. 'Tis like findin' a hidden treasure in the sandy coves, a treasure more precious than all the doubloons in the world. Me thoughts be consumed by the memory of yer laughter, as joyous as the melodies playin' in a seaside tavern.

Me fair lass, the way ye move be like the graceful sway of a ship in calm waters, and the touch of yer hand be softer than the finest silks of the East Indies. Ye've captured me heart and soul, and I'd traverse the seven seas just to see the warmth of yer smile once more.

As I sit by the firelight, starin' into the vast ocean that separates us, I dream of the day when fate shall guide our ships to meet once more. 'Tis a day I yearn for, a day when I can hold ye close and whisper sweet words into yer ear, words as sweet as the tropical fruits that grow on these isles.

Until that day comes, me love, know that me heart sails with ye, no matter how far apart we be. Ye be the North Star that guides me through the darkest of nights, the gentle breeze that fills me sails, and the anchor that steadies me in the storm. May the winds of fortune blow us back together, and may the tides of destiny carry us to a shore where our love can flourish as wildly as the palms that line these sandy beaches.

With all the love a pirate's heart can muster,

Using AI to code anything besides some "busy work" invites the situation wherein a subtle bug can get through the cracks.  I can only hope they don't use it for security control..

Seriously, what makes you think that, "subtle bugs" don't get introduced by human programmers ALL THE TIME?  As a professional in the field, I can assure you that QA regression testing is a notoriously weak part of the development ecosystem.  Businesses don't want to waste time and money on extensive testing.  Here's the thing (and I'm going to use fully self-driving cars as an example), most people think the self driving AI has to be perfect, when in fact it only needs to be better than us.  If the insurance company finds that a human truck driver has, on average 1 accident in 50,000 miles of driving, whereas an AI system has one wreck in 200,000 miles, the insurance company is going to charge significantly lower rates for the AI driven truck.

@@MCart1215 I wouldnt say end times at all, but this rate of change in technology hasn't occurred ever in history. It will likely make the information age look extremely slow comparatively, and many people still struggle keeping up with the online space. Its too much information for our monkey brains to take in, and we've come to resent its social impacts. AI and AR/VR/MR are setting up to make that even worse, without considering the social costs. And on top of all this, its a global phenomenon with winner takes all stakes. Ive been a computer systems engineer for 30 years and have some experience with neural networks, plus some parallel fields. I have colleagues who are very concerned about where things are heading. These are smart people, and we all watched the information age arrive and were very well positioned to be able to understand it and utilise it. But that confidence isnt there this time, and it seems no one can keep up at all. The power of anything close to an AGI cant be understated but more important is the exponential, positive feedback loop that underpins it all. Governments could quickly find themselves at the mercy of the new wave of technocrats.. in fact, it looks highly likely. It doesn't require an End Times for things to start looking really bleak.

@@caydenpo1001 In a future where AGI and personal robots become as ubiquitous as personal computers or iPhones, it is highly likely that corporations would become obsolete. A powerful AGI system would likely be responsible for designing and maintaining the economic system that exists.

Consider this potential future scenario: One hundred years from now, an individual's personal AGI would design a car, while their personal robots would venture to a remote mountain location to extract the necessary materials and construct the vehicle. In this case, who would the person need to pay? Traditional manufacturing factories, as we know them today, would not be required, and no monetary exchange would take place.

Such a future would undoubtedly lead to massive societal changes, and the described scenario is just one of many possibilities that could unfold. Depending on the direction it takes, humanity could find itself in a literal utopia or dystopia.
